DataElement.preferredName: Individual Cancer History of Any Treatments Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The history of any known treatments for an individual.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Individual Cancer History History of any Treatments
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A record of a patient's medical background regarding the occurrence of cancer and cancer-related problems._The history of known treatments for an individual.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A record of a patient's medical background regarding the occurrence of cancer and cancer-related problems.

Concepts.definition: A record of a patient's medical background regarding the occurrence of cancer and cancer-related problems.

Property.preferredName: Is there a History of any Treatments
Property.preferredDefinition: A question about whether a treatment history exists.

Concepts.definition: The history of known treatments for an individual.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

DataElementConcept.origin: CPTAC: Clinical Proteomic Tumor Analysis Consortium
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 11/10/19 jk Released per CPTAC SME (Linda) for Medical History CRF.  6-20-19 tt created for CPTAC Medical History CRF.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Therapeutic procedures distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process.: Not otherwise specified.

Concepts.definition: An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process.
Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target or the whole body to radiation. Radiation therapy is often used as part of curative therapy and occasionally as a component of palliative treatment for cancer. Other uses include total body irradiation prior to transplantation.

Concepts.definition: Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target or the whole body to radiation. Radiation therapy is often used as part of curative therapy and occasionally as a component of palliative treatment for cancer. Other uses include total body irradiation prior to transplantation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process.: Any natural, endogenously-derived, synthetic or semi-synthetic compound with pharmacologic activity. A pharmacologic substance has one or more specific mechanism of action(s) through which it exerts one or more effect(s) on the human or animal body. They can be used to potentially prevent, diagnose, treat or relieve symptoms of a disease. Formulation specific agents and some combination agents are also classified as pharmacologic substances.

Concepts.definition: An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process.

Any natural, endogenously-derived, synthetic or semi-synthetic compound with pharmacologic activity. A pharmacologic substance has one or more specific mechanism of action(s) through which it exerts one or more effect(s) on the human or animal body. They can be used to potentially prevent, diagnose, treat or relieve symptoms of a disease. Formulation specific agents and some combination agents are also classified as pharmacologic substances.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A diagnostic or treatment procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue; of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.

Concepts.definition: A diagnostic or treatment procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue; of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Added OBIB alternate name and identifier DW 03-21-2019
ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 2023.1.20 Alt VM added per ticket request CADSR0001943. ak

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 1/25/23 added alt name for ticket number CADSR0001948 for CCTG cjl.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Cancer therapies designed to act upon specific molecules in metabolic pathways or processes involved in carcinogenesis, tumor growth, or tumor spread.

Concepts.definition: Cancer therapies designed to act upon specific molecules in metabolic pathways or processes involved in carcinogenesis, tumor growth, or tumor spread.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Therapy designed to induce changes in a patient's immune status in order to treat disease.

Concepts.definition: Therapy designed to induce changes in a patient's immune status in order to treat disease.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Various treatment modalities that produce the desired therapeutic effect by means of change of hormone/hormones level. The treatment may include administration of hormones or hormone analogs to the patient, or decreasing the level of hormones in the body by using hormone antagonists, or hormone ablation therapy.

Concepts.definition: Various treatment modalities that produce the desired therapeutic effect by means of change of hormone/hormones level.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The use of synthetic or naturally-occurring chemicals for the treatment of diseases.

Concepts.definition: The use of synthetic or naturally-occurring chemicals for the treatment of diseases.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of radiation therapy in which a radioactive substance, such radioactive iodine or a radioactively labeled monoclonal antibody, is swallowed or injected into the body and travels through the blood, locating and killing tumor cells.

Concepts.definition: Radiation therapy in which radioactive drugs are administered orally or through an injection then circulate through the blood and collect in tumor sites where they kill cancer cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of radiation therapy in which radioactive material sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters is placed directly into or near a tumor.

Concepts.definition: A type of radiation therapy in which radioactive material is placed inside the body, into a tumor or body cavity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of radiation therapy that uses a machine to aim high-energy rays at the cancer from outside of the body.

Concepts.definition: Radiation therapy in which high-energy beams are delivered to the tumor from outside of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not accompanied by another or others; exclusive of anyone or anything else.: A diagnostic or treatment procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue; of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.

Concepts.definition: Not accompanied by another or others; exclusive of anyone or anything else.

A diagnostic or treatment procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue; of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.: An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process.

Concepts.definition: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.
An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A method of hematopoietic reconstitution, Peripheral Stem Cell Transplants utilize (transfuse) hematopoietic stem cells harvested from circulating blood of an autologous, syngeneic, or allogeneic donor to reconstitute the bone marrow of the transplant recipient. Peripheral stem cell transplants are performed following partial or complete bone marrow ablation of a patient, done as therapy for certain blood diseases or following high dose chemotherapy or radiation treatment for cancer. (NCI04)

Concepts.definition: A method of hematopoietic reconstitution, Peripheral Stem Cell Transplants utilize (transfuse) hematopoietic stem cells harvested from circulating blood of an autologous, syngeneic, or allogeneic donor to reconstitute the bone marrow of the transplant recipient. Peripheral stem cell transplants are performed following partial or complete bone marrow ablation of a patient, done as therapy for certain blood diseases or following high dose chemotherapy or radiation treatment for cancer. (NCI04)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not characterized in any other way.: Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target or the whole body to radiation. Radiation therapy is often used as part of curative therapy and occasionally as a component of palliative treatment for cancer. Other uses include total body irradiation prior to transplantation.

Concepts.definition: Not characterized in any other way.

Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target or the whole body to radiation. Radiation therapy is often used as part of curative therapy and occasionally as a component of palliative treatment for cancer. Other uses include total body irradiation prior to transplantation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Anticancer drugs that kill cells, especially cancer cells.

Concepts.definition: A drug therapy that is used to destroy cancer cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Radiation treatment modality used as major component in treatment of primary and metastatic brain tumors. This is a standard treatment for multiple brain metastases.

Concepts.definition: Radiation treatment modality used as major component in treatment of primary and metastatic brain tumors. This is a standard treatment for multiple brain metastases.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of external radiation therapy that uses special equipment to position the patient and precisely give a single large dose of radiation to a tumor. It is used to treat brain tumors and other brain disorders that cannot be treated by regular surgery. It is also being studied in the treatment of other types of cancer.

Concepts.definition: A non-surgical procedure that was developed to deliver one or several maximum dose targeted radiation treatments for cancers in the brain or spine.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stereotactic radiation therapy in which one or several maximum dose radiation treatments are delivered targeting cancers of the body, excluding the brain or spine.

Concepts.definition: Stereotactic radiation therapy in which one or several maximum dose radiation treatments are delivered targeting cancers of the body, excluding the brain or spine.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of external beam radiation therapy using a beam of protons. It has the advantage of precisely localizing the radiation dose on the targeted tissue and avoiding damage to the healthy surrounding tissues.

Concepts.definition: A type of external beam radiation therapy using a beam of protons. It has the advantage of precisely localizing the radiation dose on the targeted tissue and avoiding damage to the healthy surrounding tissues.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not characterized in any other way.: Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target or the whole body to radiation. Radiation therapy is often used as part of curative therapy and occasionally as a component of palliative treatment for cancer. Other uses include total body irradiation prior to transplantation.

Concepts.definition: Not characterized in any other way.

Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target or the whole body to radiation. Radiation therapy is often used as part of curative therapy and occasionally as a component of palliative treatment for cancer. Other uses include total body irradiation prior to transplantation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An advanced form of 3-Dimensional Conformal Radiation Therapy

Concepts.definition: An advanced form of 3-Dimensional Conformal Radiation Therapy (3D CRT) that involves the use of varying intensities of small radiation beams to produce dosage distributions that are more precise than those possible with 3D CRT.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Internal radiation treatment that targets a cancerous tissue with low doses of radiation through the use of inserted temporary or permanent implants.

Concepts.definition: Internal radiation treatment that targets a cancerous tissue with low doses of radiation through the use of inserted temporary or permanent implants.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Internal radiation treatment that targets a cancerous tissue with accurate, high doses of radiation through the use of inserted temporary implants.

Concepts.definition: Internal radiation treatment that targets a cancerous tissue with accurate, high doses of radiation through the use of inserted temporary implants.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A process by which a dose of radiation is automatically shaped to closely conform to the entire volume of the tumor, so that surrounding normal tissue is spared and treatment toxicity is decreased.

Concepts.definition: A process by which a dose of radiation is automatically shaped to closely conform to the entire volume of the tumor, so that surrounding normal tissue is spared and treatment toxicity is decreased.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Palliative care is the patient-and family-centered active holistic care of patients with advanced, progressive disease. Traditional models reflect abandonment of proactive treatment and a simultaneous increase in symptom control and comfort-related services, as a disease progressed in linear fashion through its course. Essential components of palliative care are: pain and symptom control, communication regarding treatment and alternatives, prognosis, and available services, rehabilitation services, care that addresses treatment and palliative concerns, intellectual, emotional, social, and spiritual needs, terminal care, support in bereavement. The goal of palliative care is an achievement of the best quality of life for patients and their families.

Concepts.definition: The patient- and family-centered active holistic care of patients with advanced, progressive disease. Essential components of palliative care are: pain and symptom control, communication regarding treatment and alternatives, prognosis, and available services, rehabilitation services, care that addresses treatment and palliative concerns, intellectual, emotional, social, and spiritual needs, terminal care, support in bereavement. The goal of palliative care is an achievement of the best quality of life for patients and their families.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Removal, separation, detachment, extirpation, or eradication of a body part, pathway, or function by surgery, chemical destruction, morbid process, or noxious substance.

Concepts.definition: Removal, separation, detachment, extirpation, or eradication of a body part, pathway, or function by surgery, chemical destruction, morbid process, or noxious substance.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A treatment modality that uses directed electromagnetic waves within the microwave spectrum to heat the targeted tissue for the purpose of causing tissue necrosis within solid tissue tumors.

Concepts.definition: A treatment modality that uses directed electromagnetic waves within the microwave spectrum to heat the targeted tissue for the purpose of causing tissue necrosis within solid tissue tumors.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A therapeutic procedure to eradicate or reduce small tumors using radiowaves to generate heat. The procedure is performed by the insertion of a thin needle through the skin and into a tumor, which is guided by computed tomography (CT) or ultrasound. Electrical energy delivered through this needle (electrode) heats and destroys the tumor. This therapeutic option is widely utilized by patients that have inoperable cancers, or are unsuitable chemotherapy candidates.

Concepts.definition: A therapeutic procedure to kill tissue using radiowaves to generate heat. The procedure is performed by the insertion of an electrode into a target tissue. Electrical energy delivered to the electrode heats and destroys the tissue.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of external radiation therapy that uses special equipment to position the patient and precisely give a single large dose of radiation to a tumor. It is used to treat brain tumors and other brain disorders that cannot be treated by regular surgery. It is also being studied in the treatment of other types of cancer.

Concepts.definition: A surgical procedure to treat cancer cells that use high energy beams.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A treatment used in addition to the primary therapy.

Concepts.definition: A treatment used in addition to the primary therapy.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Drug treatment to prevent, stop, or reduce the severity of seizures or convulsions, commonly used in cases of epilepsy or other seizure disorders.

Concepts.definition: Drug treatment to prevent, stop, or reduce the severity of seizures or convulsions, commonly used in cases of epilepsy or other seizure disorders.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The use of biphosphonate compounds to treat low bone density or fragile bone conditions.

Concepts.definition: The use of biphosphonate compounds to treat low bone density or fragile bone conditions.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A clinical study that is designed using a procedure in which one or more parties to the study [subject(s), investigator(s), monitor, or/and data analyst(s)] are kept unaware of the treatment assignment(s).

Concepts.definition: A clinical study that is designed using a procedure in which one or more parties to the study [subject(s), investigator(s), monitor, or/and data analyst(s)] are kept unaware of the treatment assignment(s).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A procedure in which the blood supply to the tumor is blocked surgically or mechanically and anticancer drugs are administered directly into the tumor. This permits a higher concentration of drug to be in contact with the tumor for a longer period of time.

Concepts.definition: A procedure that introduces chemotherapy to blood vessels adjacent to a tumor, for the purpose of both treating the tumor and interrupt blood flow to the tumor, which serves both to trap the chemotherapeutic agent at the tumor and to decrease the amount of nutrients flowing to the tumor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Chemicals which protect normal cells from the effects of chemotherapy.

Concepts.definition: Chemicals which protect normal cells from the effects of chemotherapy.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Treatment in which radiation therapy is administered at the same time as chemotherapy.

Concepts.definition: Treatment in which radiation therapy is administered at the same time as chemotherapy.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (EM-bo-lih-ZAY-shun) The blocking of an artery by a clot or foreign material. Embolization can be done as treatment to block the flow of blood to a tumor.

Concepts.definition: A procedure in which substances are injected into blood vessels adjacent to a tumor for the purpose of interrupting the blood flow to the cancer cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Radiation Therapy that uses iodine I-131. It is typically used to treat thyroid conditions.

Concepts.definition: Radiation Therapy that uses iodine I-131. It is typically used to treat thyroid conditions.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A procedure used to deliver anticancer drugs directly to an arm or leg but not to the rest of the body. The flow of blood to and from the limb is temporarily stopped with a tourniquet (a tight band around the limb). Catheters (small, flexible tubes) attached to a pump are put into an artery and a vein in the limb so that blood can be circulated through the pump into the limb. Anticancer drugs are injected into the catheters. Wrapping the limb in a heated blanket or warming the drugs or blood may help the drugs work better.

Concepts.definition: A procedure used to deliver anticancer drugs directly to an arm or leg but not to the rest of the body. The flow of blood to and from the limb is temporarily stopped with a tourniquet (a tight band around the limb). Catheters (small, flexible tubes) attached to a pump are put into an artery and a vein in the limb so that blood can be circulated through the pump into the limb. Anticancer drugs are injected into the catheters. Wrapping the limb in a heated blanket or warming the drugs or blood may help the drugs work better.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The transfer of an organ, organ part, or tissue from one body to another, for the purpose of replacing the recipient's damaged or failing organ with a working one from the donor. Donors can be living, or cadaveric (dead).

Concepts.definition: The transfer of an organ, organ part, or tissue from one body to another, for the purpose of replacing the recipient's damaged or failing organ with a working one from the donor. Donors can be living, or cadaveric (dead).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Treatment of disease through the use of drugs.

Concepts.definition: Treatment of disease through the use of drugs.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A therapeutic surgical procedure in which the pleural space is surgically eliminated by the adherence of the visceral and parietal pleurae.

Concepts.definition: A therapeutic surgical procedure in which the pleural space is surgically eliminated by the adherence of the visceral and parietal pleurae.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A surgical procedure in which talc is insufflated into the pleural space during thoracoscopy to promote the adhesion of the visceral and parietal layers of the pleura as a treatment for recurring pleural effusion.

Concepts.definition: A surgical procedure in which talc is insufflated into the pleural space during thoracoscopy to promote the adhesion of the visceral and parietal layers of the pleura as a treatment for recurring pleural effusion.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A course of radiotherapy where minimal imaging support (i.e. X-rays films) is used to determine the positioning of radiotherapy.

Concepts.definition: A course of radiotherapy where minimal imaging support (i.e. X-rays films) is used to determine the positioning of radiotherapy.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Simultaneous or consecutive use of radiotherapy and one or more non-radiation based treatment modalities.

Concepts.definition: Simultaneous or consecutive use of radiotherapy and one or more non-radiation based treatment modalities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A proprietary, robotic radiosurgery system designed to deliver precise beams of high does radiation to tumors with extreme accuracy.

Concepts.definition: A proprietary, robotic radiosurgery system designed to deliver precise beams of high dose radiation to tumors with extreme accuracy.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Radiation therapy in which high-energy beams are delivered to the tumor from outside of the body.

Concepts.definition: Radiation therapy in which high-energy beams are delivered to the tumor from outside of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Radiation treatment in which the total dose of radiation is divided into large doses and treatments are given less than once a day.

Concepts.definition: Radiation treatment in which the total dose of radiation is divided into large doses and treatments are given less than once a day.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of internal radiation therapy in which radioactive material sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters is placed directly into a tumor or body tissue. (Cancer.gov)

Concepts.definition: A type of internal radiation therapy in which radioactive material sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters is placed directly into a tumor or body tissue. (Cancer.gov)

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Direct Mixed Photon and Electron Field
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A radiation therapy technique where external photon and electron beams are used to deliver treatment of superficial and deep-seated malignancies, respectively, while sparing underlying organs at risk.

Concepts.longName: Direct Mixed Photon and Electron Field
Concepts.definition: A radiation therapy technique where external photon and electron beams are used to deliver treatment of superficial and deep-seated malignancies, respectively, while sparing underlying organs at risk.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Radiation therapy using photon beam.

Concepts.definition: Radiation therapy using photon beam.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target to radioisotopes.

Concepts.definition: Treatment of a disease by means of exposure of the target to radioisotopes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of radiation therapy in which a radioactive substance, such radioactive iodine or a radioactively labeled monoclonal antibody, is swallowed or injected into the body and travels through the blood, locating and killing tumor cells.

Concepts.definition: Radiation therapy in which radioactive drugs are administered orally or through an injection then circulate through the blood and collect in tumor sites where they kill cancer cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The use of radioactive iodine to treat disease.

Concepts.definition: The use of radioactive iodine to treat disease.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of radiation therapy used to treat liver cancer that is advanced or has come back. Tiny beads that hold the radioisotope yttrium Y 90 are injected into the hepatic artery (the main blood vessel that carries blood to the liver). The beads collect in the tumor and the yttrium Y 90 gives off radiation. This destroys the blood vessels that the tumor needs to grow and kills the cancer cells. Radioembolization is a type of selective internal radiation therapy (SIRT).

Concepts.definition: A combination therapy for cancer treatment that couples radiation therapy and embolization through the introduction of radioactive microspheres directly into vessels supplying the tumor, allowing for the delivery of high dose radiation without irradiating healthy tissue.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Drugs used to potentiate the effectiveness of radiation therapy in destroying unwanted cells.

Concepts.definition: An agent that makes tumor cells more sensitive to radiation therapy.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A clinical treatment in which HSC capable of reconstituting the immune system and blood production (hematopoiesis) are transferred from one genetically dissimilar individual to another. The donor and recipient may or may not be related. 2005

Concepts.definition: A clinical treatment in which hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) are transferred from one genetically dissimilar individual to another.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The transference of stem cells within the same individual.

Concepts.definition: Stem cell transfer or transplantation in which the patient is their own donor.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Autologous-Autologous Tandem Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Therapy that combines cytoreductive-therapy from high-dose therapy and autologous hematopoietic cell transplantation with adoptive immunotherapy (from autologous hematopoietic cell transplantation) as a treatment strategy for multiple myeloma.

Concepts.longName: Autologous-Autologous Tandem Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation
Concepts.definition: Therapy that combines cytoreductive-therapy from high-dose therapy and autologous hematopoietic cell transplantation with adoptive immunotherapy (from autologous hematopoietic cell transplantation) as a treatment strategy for multiple myeloma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A clinical treatment in which hematopoietic stem cells are transferred from a HLA half-matched donor to a recipient.

Concepts.definition: A clinical treatment in which hematopoietic stem cells are transferred from a HLA half-matched donor to a recipient.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Nonmyeloablative Allogeneic Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A modification of the standard method of allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation developed to allow for the therapy to be extended to a patient population that is unable to tolerate treatment with the conventional procedure due to its toxicity.

Concepts.longName: Nonmyeloablative Allogeneic Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation
Concepts.definition: A modification of the standard method of allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation developed to allow for the therapy to be extended to a patient population that is unable to tolerate treatment with the conventional procedure due to its toxicity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A therapeutic procedure that involves the transplantation of hematopoietic stem cells, either with the patient as their own donor or from a donor to a patient. This can be used for treatment of malignant and non-malignant diseases.

Concepts.definition: A therapeutic procedure that involves the transplantation of hematopoietic stem cells, either with the patient as their own donor or from a donor to a patient. This can be used for treatment of malignant and non-malignant diseases.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No value exists.

Concepts.definition: No value exists.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A treatment modality that leverages stem cells to prevent or treat disease.

Concepts.definition: A treatment modality that leverages stem cells to prevent or treat disease.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Treatment with corticosteroid drugs to reduce swelling, pain, and other symptoms of inflammation.

Concepts.definition: The use of exogenous steroids for the treatment of any disease or disorder.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 2023.3.7 Alt VM added per ticket request CADSR0002119. ak

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not provided or available.

Concepts.definition: Not provided or available.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 10/10/23 changed Long Name from "Not Stated" to match NCIt Preferred name and current caDSR concept Long Name of "Not Reported" per Brenda.Janice . LS

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The use of extreme cold to damage or destroy a body part, pathway, or function. The procedure is performed using small cryogenic probes during surgery, and has recently been applied to solitary sporadic renal tumor lesions.

Concepts.definition: The use of extreme cold to damage or destroy a body part, pathway, or function. The procedure is performed using small cryogenic probes during surgery, and has recently been applied to solitary sporadic renal tumor lesions.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An injection of ethanol (alcohol) through the skin directly into a tumor to kill cancer cells. Ultrasound or a CT scan is used to guide the needle into the tumor.

Concepts.definition: An injection of ethanol (alcohol) through the skin directly into a tumor to kill cancer cells. Ultrasound or a CT scan is used to guide the needle into the tumor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Therapy designed to induce changes in a patient's immune status in order to treat disease._Including the stated limits._Preparations containing substances with antigenic properties administered to activate the immune system, thereby inducing an immune response.

Concepts.definition: Therapy designed to induce changes in a patient's immune status in order to treat disease.
Including the stated limits.
Preparations containing substances with antigenic properties administered to activate the immune system, thereby inducing an immune response.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueDomain.changeDescription: New version created. 6-19-19- tt added "Unknown" PV for CPTAC. 5-21-19 tt added one PV. Created for CDDP LUAD clinical data form per request by K.Wildermuth. mc 1/13/2016
ValueDomain.administrativeNotes: 10/17/23 Versioned to delete ~46 PVs to comply w CRDC PV list. mr

ReferenceDocuments.name: CPTAC-1
ReferenceDocuments.description: History of any Treatments (Surgery, Radiation Therapy, Chemotherapy, Molecular Targeted Therapy, Immunotherapy, Other, None, Unknown)
